title: Things to do in London this weekend
text: London weekend weather forecast There's a fairly pleasant weekend in store for London . Other than some showers on Friday it's expected to be a mild and sunny weekend. This London weather forecast is generated by the Met Office Weather Widget Here are a few events to help you make the most of the coming days. Gladiator Games; Guildhall Yard Ambitiously, the Museum of London this week brings gladiators back to the site of London’s only Roman amphitheatre, found at the Guildhall in the City. It was here that gladiators fought 2,000 years ago, and in a somewhat less brutal re-enactment of those devastating battles, fighters will gather to prove their physical supremacy and secure their future. These Gladiator Games promise to be quite a spectacle but there’s more in store throughout the games. As well as watching the battles rage on, the audience can participate in less rabid pursuits. Roman pottery classes, music lessons and cookery sessions are all on offer, while there’ll also be a chance to tour Roman ruins and explore the streets of Londinium. When: Saturday August 8 to Monday August 10, and Friday August 14 to Sunday August 16 Where: The Guildhall Yard, off Gresham Street, London EC2V 5AE Getting there: by Tube to St Paul's, Bank or Moorgate Cost: £15; children £10; concessions £12.50 London Korean Festival There is, of course, so much more to Korea than kimchi and K-pop, but you can still expect both to feature in this Sunday’s London Korean Festival . Held in Trafalgar Square, the event will provide a showcase for the country’s creative talents, with entertainment on the day including a K-Pop concert, culinary displays, creative workshops, screenings and more. When: Sunday August 9 Where: Trafalgar Square Getting there: by Tube to Charing Cross Cost: free • The best hotels in central London Shakespearean London tour Dr Matthew Green, historian, broadcaster and author of London: A Travel Guide through Time, has a knack for revealing the most unexpected details of London’s multifaceted past in fascinating and accessible detail – a frequent Telegraph contributor, his intriguing features on London’s lost coffee houses and forgotten chocolate houses are recommended. This weekend modern-day Londoners can engage with him and the city’s mottled history first-hand by joining a tour of Shakespearean London . Over the afternoon, the group will learn of the violence offered by audiences at the Globe, visit a Southwark stew (the Clink prison) and learn about the unexpectedly rarefied world of London’s disappeared tobacco houses . And should you miss this weekend's tour, others will follow on a monthy basis. When: Saturday August 8 Where: the walking tour is centred around the South Bank Cost: £10 The surprising history of London's lost tobacco houses, revealed by @drmatthewgreen http://t.co/AyzW78z9n7 pic.twitter.com/shfJsm4BFe — Telegraph Travel (@TelegraphTravel) August 5, 2015 Grimeborn; Dalston “An opera festival like no other”, Grimeborn dispenses with the black-tie dresscode and sometimes stuffy atmosphere associated with these types of gatherings to instead host “opera for everyone, with ticket prices to match”. Alongside radically reimagined classics by the likes of Verdi and Strauss, all ilk of opera fans are catered to with revived works from the past and brand new works which highlight the diversity of modern opera. When: until Saturday August 29 Where: Arcola Theatre, 24 Ashwin Street, Dalston, E8 3DL Getting there: by Overground to Dalston Junction or Dalston Kingsland Cost: prices vary; an Arcola Passport allows you to see five shows for £50 or less First night Boheme absolutely wonderful! If the rest are half as good this will be a treat of a festival. https://t.co/u8J3SqDa9X — Brendan Martin (@BrendanFMartin) August 4, 2015 • The best hotels in central London Rich Mix Youth Takeover, Shoreditch An exciting initiative at Rich Mix gives young people aged from 16 to 25 the opportunity to immerse themselves in all the arts venue has to offer. Throughout much of August, a substantial core component of the centre’s programme will be dedicated to events and activities that cater specifically to that demographic. There’s plenty to choose from, with theatre shows and musical performances scheduled alongside vlogging workshops, debates and writing masterclasses. When: until Saturday August 22 Where: Rich Mix, 35-47 Bethnal Green Road, E1 6LA Getting there: by Tube to Liverpool Street or Old Street; Overground to Shoreditch High Street Cost: prices vary • The best hotels in central London Want to get out of the city instead?
